title: Montessori?? How to raise smart babies (+ kids!)
description:
How do we play with our babies? How do we educate our babies? Let's talk about baby toys, child development, optimal learning environments & how to grow our baby's brain right from birth.

Hi friends! When it comes to child development and education our babies I honestly do not spend much time thinking about how I will help to grow my baby's brain. I love my children and I know their educations matter, but between the responsibility of day to day tasks, and the overall goal of keeping my kids alive and loves .. very little of my mental space goes to asking questions like .. what is the optimal learning environment for my baby?.. how can I teach my baby to crawl, grasp, walk, & think curiously? .. how can I help children be explorers who use their imaginations & have longer attention spans? .. In this video I talk about baby play and how we as parents and educators can be more intentional about our style of play and the toys we use to engage our babies and young children. Montessori has some brilliant ideas, originating from Marta Montessori of Italy, so I have tried to incorporate some of their beliefs into this video to support you in educating your child. I don't personally believe in spending a lot of money of baby toys.. I also don't think you need to read to your child every night.. or at the hospital when the baby is born.. or really anything that is going to cause further exhaustion or stress to a new parent's life ... that is not my style. I love the idea of incorporating little intentional moments of exploration into your child's life, in nearly effortless ways. From creating a simple beautiful environment for baby to spend time in, with less toys .. which means less clean up for you! To adding songs, stories, laughter, and just general talking to your normal everyday routines. There are easy things you can do to .. "grow your baby's brain" .. if that is your concern, and there are fun options for educating your little ones that don't have to be costly or tiring. 

YOU ARE A GREAT MOM. Have grace with yourself and do what you can to enjoy the motherhood role .. however tiring, confusing, emotional, fun and crazy it sometimes is. Thank you for letting me support you in it! 

Raising kids with Healthy Body Image: https://youtu.be/7iEvZyUJqdQ

See you on instagram! @jess_Hover

title: Montessori Vs. Conventional School
description:
The Montessori Method is an inclusive educational method that was formed by Dr. Maria Montessori in which it delves into the perception of children's preferred learning modalities as they develop. The classroom environment consists of attractive manipulatives, educational toys that involve children in academic learning. "The Montessori classroom is a "prepared environment" planned in advance to support independent, student-initiated work." In the classroom, children are free to select manipulative's of their preference and through curiosity and innate interest engage in learning activities of their own individual choice. In the traditional Montessori environment, children manipulate objects and discover the joy of learning while a teacher guides them and "... by making discoveries with the materials, cultivating concentration, motivation, self-discipline, and a love of learning."

The traditional classroom setting consists of a teacher assigned to a group of students. Rather than guiding children through learning, the teacher's role is to instruct students. The job of the teacher is to provide each student with a firm foundation and enrich their minds by teaching the grade-level standards. In this setting, the teacher delivers the curriculum from textbooks, with an outline of the lesson to be taught that day. The students are seated in chairs or tables, either working by themselves or in collaborative groups, contingent on the set up of the classroom. In this setting, there exists a variety of learners however the teacher teaches from a whole group perspective. The outcome of student learning relies heavily on assessments or tests. Rather than constructively learning through manipulating their environment, the students in this setting are taught in a very structured environment. For more information visit our Website at WWW.EXCELLENTMONTESSORI.NET.

title: How to Teach Reading the Montessori Way Part 2: Letter Recognition with the Sandpaper Letters
description:
How to Teach Reading the Montessori Way, Part 2: Letter Recognition with the Sandpaper Letters

My Montessori reading video ended up being really long, so I split it into 3 parts.  See Part 1: Introduction, Creating a Language-Rich Environment, and the Sound Game here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oJsgDoZHr7w

In Part 2, I will go over letter recognition with the sandpaper letters and activities that you can do with your child to review and reinforce the phonetic sounds of the letters and some double-letter phonograms.

title: How to Choose a Montessori Preschool
description:
Choosing a Montessori preschool can be challenging. The Montessori primary (age 3-6) classroom environment is very different from other preschools, and many parents find it hard to know what to look for when choosing a Montessori school. This video highlights key attributes of a well-run, authentic Montessori preschool: the classroom environment, the teaching approach and the children's behavior and capabilities. This video was taken in Fall 2010 at LePort Montessori in Orange County, CA. Learn more about our schools and the authentic Montessori approach we take at www.leport.com.

LePort Montessori Schools: www.leport.com
Why LePort Montessori: www.leport.com/why-leport/
Our Programs: www.leport.com/programs/

See our locations in California, New York, and Virginia: www.leport.com/locations

title: Montessori School Education
description:
To help us to make more such videos, visit http://www.patreon.com/sprouts

Montessori Education is based on the principles developed by Maria Montessori, who opened her first school for children of low-income workers in an apartment building in Rome in 1907. The school was called “Casa Dei Bambini”, Home for Children.

This first “Casa” was furnished with a teacher's table, a stove, a blackboard, some chairs, group tables for the children and a cabinet filled with materials that Montessori developed in her earlier career when she researched how to teach kids who experience some form of mental disability. 
Maria Montessori created the materials after she realized that students seem to understand complex concepts better when they engaged all their senses.

Activities at this first school included personal care (such as dressing and undressing), care of the environment like sweeping, dusting and gardening. Otherwise, they were free to move around and play with the materials. Montessori did not teach herself but instead oversaw the classroom work of her teachers.

Montessori observed that children showed episodes of deep concentration and multiple repetitions of the same activity. Given free choice, kids showed more interest in practical activities and the materials than normal toys, sweets or other rewards. Over time spontaneous self-discipline emerged.

Montessori concluded that working independently children seemed to reach new levels of autonomy and become self-motivated learners. She began to see the role of the teacher as a facilitator of young human beings who are free to move and act within the limits of a prepared environment. The goal: to grow children to become independent and responsible adults who share a love for learning.

Soon after Montessori herself and her ideas started traveling the world to inspired progressive thinkers and educators from all over. The inventors, Alexander Graham Bell and Thomas Edison, became early advocates. Later alumni include Jimmy Wales from Wikipedia, author Gabriel Garcia Marquez as well as the two Google founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin.

Today the term “Montessori” stands more for a method, than a school itself. The fact that it can be used freely by anyone led to a great variation of schools. Educators all over the world borrow Montessori's name, insights, and materials to organize kindergartens, elementary schools, special needs programs, or even full 12-year curriculums. Some parents use it for homeschooling.


The following characteristics are shared among most programs:

- Students are free to choose what to learn
- Open classrooms that allow free movement
- Use of specialized Montessori materials 
- Mixed-age classes (from 0-3, 3-6 or 6-12) so children can learn from each other
- Uninterrupted blocks of study time, usually three hours
- No grading or homework
- and a trained teacher

Maria Montessori once famously said: “Never help a child with a task at which he feels he can succeed.”What are your thoughts on Montessori? Please share your opinions in the comments below!

title: How to Teach Phonics | Set 1 - C, M, A, T | Montessori 3 Step Lesson
description:
Learn how to teach phonics with Montessori Principles! This is Set 1 – C, M, A, T  introducing the successful Montessori 3 Step Lesson also known as the 3 period lesson. Learn how how to teach letters to children, preschoolers and toddlers by phonetic sounds rather than letter names. I teach the letters in an order that allows children / early readers to make many words with the letters they have learned early on in the sequence.

There are variations in the sequence / order in which letters can be introduced to children / early readers. This video introduces the first set of 7 sets of letters that will be taught using the Montessori 3 period lesson in the following order (recommended by Tim Seldin author of How to Raise an Amazing Child the Montessori Way). 

Set 1 c, m, a, t - https://youtu.be/mXQkjSQiqAs
Set 2 s, r, i, p - https://youtu.be/Qu_nj28BsuA
Set 3 b, f, o, g - https://youtu.be/6HSI4F6YU_0
Set 4 h, j, u, l - https://youtu.be/8fvgy2ialhg
Set 5 d, w, e, n - https://youtu.be/V4HHjmxj4hE
Set 6 k, q, v - https://youtu.be/1j8WosCD8ec
Set 7 x, y, z -  https://youtu.be/sJrP28o5HGI

..................................................

Introduction of the letters using the time tested Montessori 3 period lesson is implemented as follows:

1. Identify the sounds of an isolated letter – “this is” 
In the first stage we will make the sounds of letters when we trace and write them, and we will also reinforce learning with objects that begin with the sounds of each letter.

When we have identified the sounds of the letters we will see if we can associate/recognize the sounds of letters in stage 2.

2. Associate/Recognize – “show me” 
In stage 2 we see the group of letters that we previously identified the sounds of and show where a letter that makes a specific sound is upon request.

3. Recall – “what is this”
In stage 3 we say the sound of the letter indicated upon request.

Montessori Sandpaper Letters are used to introduce the names and phonetic sound for each letter in preparation for reading. Tracing a letter with the fingertips whilst making the phonetic sound provides a tactile sensation to form both a visual and sensory impression to reinforce learning. This also develops a muscular memory that will help your child’s hand and mind become familiar with movements required to form each letter and be useful when s/he starts to write.

Montessori Sandpaper Letters can be purchased online or go to the description in my video at https://youtu.be/l4Y-J_mWfw0 for information on how to make DIY Montessori Sandpaper Letters.

title: How to Teach Preschoolers Numbers 1 to 10 | Montessori Sensory Activity
description:
How to Teach Preschoolers Numbers 1 to 10 | Learn to Write Numbers | Montessori Sensory Activity 

In this preschool learning video we learn numbers 1 to 10 with Montessori Number Work and a DIY Montessori Sand Tray / Salt Tray to reinforce learning of numbers 1 to 10. We also learn how to write / trace numbers 1 to 10 with a Montessori preschool sensorial exercise / sensory activity using both Montessori sandpaper letters and a DIY Montessori Sand Tray / Salt Tray that teach your toddler / preschooler basic numbers 1 to 10. 

We follow the Montessori method by introducing the numbers 1 to 10 as quantities to count before moving on to the numerals. Cumulative red and blue tabs based on the counting rods found in Montessori classrooms help preschoolers conceptualize quantities when they count the segments of the number rod as it builds up. Groupings of illustrated objects provide objects to count before readers encounter textured numerals to trace with their fingers and intensify learning with a sensory / sensorial learning experience. Learning of numbers can also be further reinforced as demonstrated in this number learning video by tracing / writing each number from 1 to 10 in a Montessori Sand Tray / Salt Tray.

title: Table Washing: Montessori Practical Life
Montessori Numbers | How To Write Numbers |  Learn to Count 1to10
description:
Montessori Numbers | How To Write Numbers |  Learn to Count 1to10

This Montessori Sandpaper Numbers tracing activity teaches the numbers 1 to 10 and shows how each number is written.  It can be used in combination with Montessori sandpaper number cards (see more information below). 

Montessori Sandpaper Numbers are used to introduce the names and symbols for each numeral (in this case 1 – 10). Tracing a number with the fingertips whilst saying the name of the number provides a tactile sensation to form both a visual and sensory impression to reinforce learning.  This also develops a muscular memory that will help your child’s hand and mind become familiar with movements required to form each number and be useful when s/he starts to write numbers.

...........................

0:20 How to write number 1 - learn number 1
0:50 How to write number 2 - learn number 2
1:20 How to write number 3 - learn number 3
1:51 How to write number 4 - learn number 4
2:21 How to write number 5 - learn number 5
2:51 How to write number 6 - learn number 6
3:32 How to write number 7 - learn number 7
3:52 How to write number 8 - learn number 8
4:23 How to write number 9 - learn number 9
4:54 How to write number 10 - learn number 10
...........................

Sandpaper numbers can be purchased at Montessori material suppliers or you can make them yourself as follows:

• Print template numbers on to paper and cut them out
• Reverse the numbers and place or stick them on to the back of fine sandpaper
• Trace around the numbers on the sandpaper with a pen and cut them out
• Mount the numbers on separate green card which is about 5 x 4 inches or 12 x 10 centimetres in size

Happy Learning!

Sandpaper letter can be purchased at Montessori material suppliers or you can make them yourself as follows:

• Print template letters on to paper and cut them out
• Reverse the letters and place or stick them on to the back of fine sandpaper
• Trace around the letters on the sandpaper with a pen and cut them out
• Mount the numbers on separate cards (blue for vowels and red/pink for consonents) which is about 5 x 4 inches or 12 x 10 centimetres in size

title: Montessori Parenting Course
description:
A course to introduce parents to the Montessori philosophy and how to use it at home to raise happy, self-motivated and confident children.

Do you feel Montessori is right for your family but you are overwhelmed by your online search?

Being a qualified Montessori teacher, when I had my children (prior to Pinterest and Instagram), I felt that I had a pathway, a structure and a philosophy to refer to.

As a new parent, with no background in Montessori, how do you start? What do you need? How to make your house more Montessori?

I have designed my Montessori Parenting Course to simplify your life and to give you what you need to bring Montessori into your family life.

This course is available in 2 formats:

Self-paced E-course 
Guided course (e-course + live support within a FB group )

The next course is starting on the 11th of February.

Watch the first lesson for free here
https://bit.ly/2DH6Zce

title: How to make a HTTYD-themed Kids Bed! (DIY Montessori Bed)
description:
Jaimie and Jay make a 'How to Train Your Dragon' themed DIY Montessori Floor Bed. We believe that no child should have to grow up without a proper viking bed. 🔥🔥🔥

SUBSCRIBE ► http://bit.ly/2EypcHI 

Plans for this project will be available soon!

Want to help us make more videos?
https://patreon.com/wickedmakers

Questions? Join us in Discord!
https://discord.gg/MtrHrxa 

Want to see more of our works? 👇
http://thewickedmakers.com
http://twitter.com/wickedmakers
http://facebook.com/wickedmakers
https://pinterest.com/wickedmakers/
http://instagram.com/wickedmakers
https://www.instructables.com/member/WickedMakers/

The Montessori Bed, or "Floor Bed", is an integral part of the "Montessori Bedroom". As kids grow up and get too big for a crib, floor beds enable freedom of movement, independence, and mobility. They can move around, explore their environments, and wake up and move around without being trapped in the crib. They're awesome! Now that our kiddo is a toddler, it was time to make him a wicked awesome floor bed.

The DIY Montessori Bed we made is super extra and is Dragon and Viking themed, built to look like a Viking Longship. Specifically, we used the "How to Train Your Dragon" films as our inspiration. Jaimie worked on the film trilogy when she was at Dreamworks so we had artwork around the house that inspired us to make this awesome Dragon Montessori Bed.

This DIY project was incredibly fun to make and our son LOVES IT. If you're considering building a floor bed for your kiddos, we highly recommend it. Check out our DIY Floor Bed plans on our website if you want to follow along with this build and make your own Montessori Bed!

MATERIALS:
1x6" Pine
1x8" Pine
2x4" Pine
3/4" Plywood
Walnut-colored Stain
Milk Paint
1" Wood Screws
2.5" Machine Screws w/ 1/4" Barrel Nuts

(These are affiliate links and they help support our channel!)

title: Montessori Materials: Presenting the Large Number Cards
description: Presenting the Large Number Cards by Donna Brown, Montessori Teacher and Trainer, at Engadine and Gymea Montessori Academy. The purpose of the Large Number Cards to assist children with learning how to identify numbers 1 - 9,999 by breaking it down into ones, tens, hundreds, and thousands. While Montessori presentations are usually done in silence, for the purpose of this video, we have added additional instruction. The best age to introduce the Large Number Cards is between 4 - 5 years of age.

title: SCREENS AND MONTESSORI: How to apply Montessori Philosophy to screen time
description:
In this video, I outline some of the key philosophies from a Montessori perspective to consider when deciding how to raise your child with or start new habits surrounding screen time.

These philosophies include: freedom of movement, gaining self-confidence, freedom within boundaries, and trust in oneself. 

Seeing as Maria Montessori never lived in an age of technology as we know it today, applying Montessori philosophy to screen time HAS to be adaptive.

I hope something in here helps!
Please consider subscribing and commenting with any questions or clarifications.

Stay safe, and stay sane!
Julia

title: How to Teach Phonics | Set 5 - D, W, E, N | Montessori 3 Step Lesson
description:
Learn how to teach phonics using the successful Montessori 3 Step Lesson also known as the 3 Period Lesson. This is Set 5 introducing how to teach the letters D, W, E and N to children, preschoolers and toddlers using phonetic sounds rather than letter names. I teach the letters in an order that allows children / early readers to make many words with the letters they have learned early on in the sequence. 

There are variations in the sequence / order in which letters can be introduced to children / early readers. This video introduces the fifth set of 7 sets of letters that will be taught using the Montessori 3 period lesson in the following order (recommended by Tim Seldin author of How to Raise an Amazing Child the Montessori Way). 

Set 1 c, m, a, t - https://youtu.be/mXQkjSQiqAs
Set 2 s, r, i, p - https://youtu.be/Qu_nj28BsuA
Set 3 b, f, o, g - https://youtu.be/6HSI4F6YU_0
Set 4 h, j, u, l - https://youtu.be/8fvgy2ialhg
Set 5 d, w, e, n - https://youtu.be/V4HHjmxj4hE
Set 6 k, q, v - https://youtu.be/1j8WosCD8ec
Set 7 x, y, z -  https://youtu.be/sJrP28o5HGI

..................................................

Introduction of the letters using the time tested Montessori 3 period lesson is implemented as follows:

1. Identify the sounds of an isolated letter – “this is” 
In the first stage we will make the sounds of letters when we trace and write them, and we will also reinforce learning with objects that begin with the sounds of each letter.

When we have identified the sounds of the letters we will see if we can associate/recognize the sounds of letters in stage 2.

2. Associate/Recognize – “show me” 
In stage 2 we see the group of letters that we previously identified the sounds of and show where a letter that makes a specific sound is upon request.

3. Recall – “what is this”
In stage 3 we say the sound of the letter indicated upon request.

Montessori Sandpaper Letters are used to introduce the names and phonetic sound for each letter in preparation for reading. Tracing a letter with the fingertips whilst making the phonetic sound provides a tactile sensation to form both a visual and sensory impression to reinforce learning. This also develops a muscular memory that will help your child’s hand and mind become familiar with movements required to form each letter and be useful when s/he starts to write.

Montessori Sandpaper Letters can be purchased online or go to the description in my video at https://youtu.be/l4Y-J_mWfw0 for information on how to make DIY Montessori Sandpaper Letters.

title: Voila Montessori: First Color Box by Jeanne Marie Paynel
description:
Simple activities you can do with your child at home or on the road, by Jeanne Marie Paynel (From birth to six years) - Visit www.voilamontessori.com  

9 key points to sharing a new activity with your child:
1. Choose an age-appropriate* activity
2. Use a few words to introduce the activity
3. Give the proper language for each item used
4. Sit opposite your dominant hand so you don’t block your child’s vision of the activity (if you’re right-handed, sit to the right of the child; lefties sit on the left)
5. Slow down your movement, so your child can analyze what you’re doing
6. Do not talk when actually showing the activity
7. Only show your child a new activity when he is rested and well-fed
8. Do not interrupt or correct once your child is engaged
9. Enjoy sharing these moments with your child

title: Montessori Phonics | Learn 2 Letter Digraphs - CH, EE, ER
description:
Teach Montessori phonics and two letter Digraphs  / Montessori phonograms CH, EE and ER with this Montessori Phonics learning activity for kids which uses the time tested Montessori 3 Period Lesson. 

The Montessori 3 period lesson is implemented as follows: 

1. Identify the sounds of isolated phonograms – “this is” 
In the first stage we will make the phonogram sounds when we trace and write them, and we will also reinforce learning with words that include a given phonogram. When we have identified the phonograms we will see if we can associate/recognize the sounds in step 2. 

2. Associate/Recognize – “show me” 
In step 2 show a specified phonogram upon request. 

3. Recall – “what is this” 
In step 3 we say the sound of the phonogram indicated upon request.

Montessori Sandpaper Letters are used to introduce the phonograms in preparation for reading. Tracing the letters with the fingertips whilst making the sound provides a tactile sensation to form both a visual and sensory impression to reinforce learning. This also develops a muscular memory that will help your child’s hand and mind become familiar with movements required to form each letter and be useful when s/he starts to write. 

Montessori Sandpaper Letters can be purchased online or you can make them yourself as follows:

• Print template letters on to paper and cut them out
• Reverse the letters and place or stick them on to the back of fine sandpaper
• Trace around the letters on the sandpaper with a pen and cut them out
• Mount the numbers on separate cards (blue for vowels and red/pink for consonents) which is about 5 x 4 inches or 12 x 10 centimetres in size

title: Montessori for Babies - Cup Training
description:
Learn how to cup train your baby the Montessori way… starting as early as 6 months! With this simple method, baby will learn how to drink from a cup and eventually wean off the breast or bottle, skipping the skippy cup and straws entirely. 

The method: 

Introduce your baby a child-sized cup (“weaning cup”) as early as 6 months. Offer them many chances to handle it; also regularly model its use. After meals, offer baby sips of water from the cup. You can hold the cup at first, but let baby gradually take control. Accept that spills will and should happen. Have a towel ready to dry any messes up.

Another thing to keep in mind is that cup learning happens in stages:

First, baby must learn to pick up and grasp the cup with both hands.

Second, baby must learn to lift the cup to his mouth.

Third, the baby must learn to control his speed and aim.

Fourth, the baby must learn to take a sip.

Fifth, the baby must learn to lower the cup after drinking, and place it back on the table!

As you can see, cup training requires a lot of practice!

Luckily, cup training can be fun — especially if you start early.

Many of you might be wondering about older babies and toddlers who resist drinking from open cups, and prefer bottles or sippy cups.

Is there a fun and respectful way to get them to drink from open cups, too?

Yes! You can use fun cups, slow-flowing liquids, and a systematic approach to help overcome their resistance, as you’ll see in the short video above.

Recommended readings: 

Understanding the Human Being, by Dr. Silvana Montanaro

The Joyful Child, by Susan Mayclin Stephenson
